bioghist.p: Natalie Saxe Randall graduated from the Philadelphia High School for Girls in 1941 and the University of Pennsylvania in 1944. At the age of 24, she became Director of the Committee for Philadelphia, which spearheaded the reform movement led by the city's great post-WWII reform Democrats Joseph Clark (Mayor 1952-1956) and Richardson Dilworth (Mayor 1956-1962) against the legendarily corrupt Republican machine. Saxe remained head of the Committee until Dilworth took office as mayor in January 1956, served concurrently on the Democratic State Committee 1950-1954, and was the self-labeled "Advance Man" during Dilworth's first unsuccessful campaign for governor (1950). When Dilworth resigned his position as mayor to run again for governor in 1962, she remained his Executive Assistant and served as the chief coordinator of his campaign. When Dilworth was appointed President of the Philadelphia Board of Education in 1965 by Mayor James Tate (whose campaign Saxe helped direct), Saxe again served as Dilworth's Executive Assistant until he resigned in 1971 rather than work in any way with Frank Rizzo. Following Dilworth's retirement from pubic life, Saxe worked as a government affairs consultant and lobbyist for a Philadelphia consortium of cultural institutions (including the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and the Academy of Natural Sciences) and Lincoln University. She also worked to perpetuate the memory of Richardson Dilworth and his reform work by assisting in the attachment of his name to Philadelphia City Hall's Dilworth Plaza and the airport's Dilworth International Terminal.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Natalie Saxe Randall. Materials include: typed incoming and outgoing correspondence (originals and retained copies, respectively); notes and memoranda; drafts; typed and typeset reports; newspaper articles; photographs; address books; daily memoranda; and travel diaries.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
